Were real knights always chivalrous? Honestly, no. Many knights were violent and greedy. The code of chivalry was an IDEAL — something to strive for, not always reality. But the ideal itself was powerful. It influenced ideas about honor, justice, and good character that we still value today.

slides.prompt: Design your own COAT OF ARMS on the shield template. Divide the shield into 4 sections. In each section, draw a symbol that represents something important to you: a value you hold (courage, kindness, creativity, loyalty), a skill you are proud of, your family, or something you love. Choose colors carefully — in heraldry, gold means generosity, red means courage, blue means loyalty, green means hope. Write the meaning of each symbol.

slides.text: Knights remind us that people have always valued courage, honor, and service — even if they did not always live up to those ideals. Your coat of arms represents YOUR values and identity, just as a knight's shield represented theirs. What do you want to stand for?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the three stages of knight training, explain the code of chivalry, and design a meaningful coat of arms?

parent_notes: Knights are endlessly fascinating for children. The progression from page to squire to knight shows that mastery takes years of dedication — a great parallel to the child's own learning journey. The coat of arms activity is personal and meaningful; display it proudly. The critical thinking element (Were knights really chivalrous?) teaches children to question idealized narratives. If your child is interested, read excerpts from King Arthur legends or watch age-appropriate documentaries about medieval life. The armor discussion can connect to simple machines (levers in sword fighting, wedges in arrowheads).

title: Simple Machines — Wedges and Screws
description: Students complete the six simple machines by learning about wedges (a moving inclined plane that splits things apart) and screws (an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder). They identify these machines in everyday tools and objects.
instructions:
1. Review the four simple machines learned so far.
2. Introduce the wedge: a moving inclined plane that concentrates force.
3. Demonstrate: splitting clay with a butter knife (wedge).
4. Introduce the screw: an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder.
5. Demonstrate: wrapping a triangle of paper around a pencil to show the 'ramp.'
6. Compare a screw to a ramp spiraling upward.
7. Identify all six simple machines in compound machines.
8. Record in science journal.

slides.heading: Simple Machines
slides.subheading: Wedges and Screws — The Final Two

items: Butter knife or plastic knife (wedge demonstration)
Various screws, bolts, and jar lids
Images showing compound machines (bicycle, can opener, scissors)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a ball of clay. Have screws of different sizes visible. Cut a right triangle from paper (for the spiral demonstration). Gather images of compound machines. Set up the science journal with a '6 Simple Machines' reference page.

slides.text: We have learned lever, inclined plane, pulley, and wheel and axle. Today we complete the set! Machine #5: the WEDGE. A wedge is an inclined plane that MOVES. Instead of you moving UP the ramp, the wedge moves INTO something to split it apart. Think of an axe splitting wood or a knife cutting bread.

Try this: push the butter knife through the clay. The thin edge enters easily, and the wider part pushes the clay apart. That is a wedge in action! The thin edge concentrates your force into a small point. Axes, knives, nails, chisels, doorstops, and even your front teeth are wedges!

Machine #6: the SCREW. A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder in a spiral. Watch: wrap this paper triangle around the pencil — see how the slanted edge creates a spiral? That is the thread of a screw! Screws convert turning motion into forward motion. They hold things together with incredible force.

Look at this screw closely — see the spiral ridge (thread)? Each turn moves the screw a tiny bit deeper, like walking slowly up a very long ramp. Jar lids, light bulbs, spiral staircases, and drill bits are all screws! Now you know ALL SIX simple machines. Most real tools are COMPOUND machines — combinations of simple machines!

slides.prompt: Create a '6 Simple Machines' reference page in your science journal. For each machine, draw it, write a definition, and list 3 everyday examples: 1) Lever, 2) Inclined plane, 3) Pulley, 4) Wheel and axle, 5) Wedge, 6) Screw. Then analyze a COMPOUND machine: how many simple machines can you find in a bicycle? In scissors? In a can opener? Draw and label them.

slides.text: You now know all six simple machines — the building blocks of every tool, vehicle, and machine ever made! From ancient Egyptian ramps to modern spacecraft, every machine is built from combinations of these six basic types. Engineers are people who combine simple machines to solve problems. You think like an engineer!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify all 6 simple machines, give examples of each, and find simple machines within a compound machine?

parent_notes: Completing all six simple machines is a significant science milestone. The paper-triangle-around-pencil demonstration for screws is brilliant and memorable. The compound machine analysis (finding simple machines inside complex tools) develops systems thinking. A bicycle is an excellent compound machine to analyze: wheels and axles (wheels), levers (brake handles, pedals), screws (bolts), pulleys (chain and gears). Consider visiting a hardware store or toolbox to find examples of all six machines. This unit has natural connections to engineering and invention.

title: Medieval Folk Dance — Learning Circle and Line Dances
description: Students learn about medieval folk dancing as a form of community celebration and exercise. They learn a simple circle dance and a line dance pattern, connecting movement to rhythm and historical cultural practice.
instructions:
1. Discuss dancing in the Middle Ages: celebrations, harvest festivals, weddings.
2. Explain that folk dances were learned by everyone — no special training needed.
3. Demonstrate a simple circle dance: step-step-kick, step-step-kick.
4. Practice the circle dance to music (or clapping).
5. Demonstrate a simple line dance: forward-forward, back-back, turn.
6. Practice the line dance.
7. Perform both dances together.
8. Discuss how dance brings community together.
materials_needed: Music (medieval folk or any rhythmic music)

slides.heading: Medieval Folk Dance
slides.subheading: Dancing in Community

items: Open space large enough for dancing (living room, yard, or gym)
Music player with medieval folk music or any rhythmic music with a clear beat
Music journal and pencil for recording dance steps
slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large space for dancing. Find medieval folk music or any music with a clear, moderate tempo. If multiple family members can participate, the dances are more authentic and fun. Practice the steps yourself before teaching.

slides.text: In the Middle Ages, EVERYONE danced — kings and peasants, old and young! Dancing happened at harvest festivals, weddings, holy days, and market fairs. There were no dance studios or lessons — people learned by joining in. Folk dances were simple patterns that anyone could follow.

Let us learn a CIRCLE DANCE. Stand in a circle (or face each other if just two). The pattern is: Step RIGHT, step LEFT, step RIGHT, KICK LEFT. Step LEFT, step RIGHT, step LEFT, KICK RIGHT. Move clockwise around the circle. The rhythm is: step-step-step-kick, step-step-step-kick.

Now a LINE DANCE — everyone faces the same direction in a line. The pattern is: Walk FORWARD 4 steps (1-2-3-4). Walk BACKWARD 4 steps (1-2-3-4). Slide RIGHT 4 steps. Slide LEFT 4 steps. TURN in a full circle. Clap twice! Repeat!

slides.prompt: Practice both dances to music. Perform the circle dance 3 times and the line dance 3 times. Then create your OWN folk dance with at least 4 different moves that repeat in a pattern. Name your dance (e.g., 'The Harvest Hop' or 'The Castle Stomp'). In your music journal, write the steps of your original dance so someone else could learn it. Teach it to a family member!

slides.text: Folk dancing has been bringing communities together for thousands of years. You do not need to be a professional dancer — folk dances are for EVERYONE. Creating your own dance makes you a choreographer! Dance is one of the oldest forms of human expression, alongside music and storytelling.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform the circle and line dances in rhythm, and create an original dance pattern with at least 4 repeating moves?

parent_notes: Folk dancing connects movement, music, history, and community. The more family members who participate, the more authentic and fun it becomes. Do not worry about perfection — the point is joyful movement! The dance patterns develop rhythm awareness, coordination, and spatial awareness. Medieval folk music is available on YouTube and streaming services. If your child enjoys this, explore folk dances from other cultures: Mexican folk dance, Irish step dance, or Indian classical dance. The choreography exercise develops sequencing and creative expression.
